HealthMetric.description: Represents a health metric logged by a patient.

id.description: Unique identifier for the health metric entity.

unit.description: Unit of measurement for the health metric.

MedicationLog.title: MedicationLog
MedicationLog.description: Represents a log of medication taken by a patient.

id.description: Unique identifier for the medication log entity.

taken.description: Indicates whether the medication was taken.

takenTime.description: Time when the medication was actually taken.

Symptom.title: Symptom
Symptom.description: Represents a symptom reported by a patient.

id.description: Unique identifier for the symptom entity.

loggedAt.description: Timestamp when the symptoms were logged.

Report.title: Report
Report.description: Represents a health report generated for a patient.

id.description: Unique identifier for the report entity.

reportData.description: Data contained in the report (e.g., JSON or PDF URL).

sharedWithDoctor.description: Indicates whether the report was shared with the doctor.

sharedWithFamily.description: Indicates whether the report was shared with family.

Streak.title: Streak
Streak.description: Represents a streak achieved by a patient.

id.description: Unique identifier for the streak entity.

firestore.reasoning:
The Firestore data structure is designed to ensure security, scalability, and ease of debugging, in accordance with the principles of Authorization Independence, Clarity of Intent, DBAC (Database-Based Access Control), and QAPs (Rules are not Filters). This design prioritizes denormalization to avoid hierarchical authorization dependencies, structural segregation for homogeneous security postures, and access modeling using path-based ownership and membership maps.

*Authorization Independence:*  Each document contains all the information required to authorize access, removing the need for `get()` calls in security rules. For example, the `health_metrics` collection includes the `patientId` which is used for authorization, meaning that a rule does not need to access the patient document to ensure the `request.auth.uid` matches.

*Structural Segregation:* Data with different access requirements are stored in separate collections. User-specific data (health metrics, medication logs, symptoms, reports, streaks) are nested under `/users/{userId}`. This segregation allows for simple, collection-level security rules.

*Access Modeling:*
    *   **Path-Based Ownership:** The `/users/{userId}` path establishes clear ownership. All data nested under a user's document is owned by that user.
    *   **Membership Map for Shared Access:** The `sharedWithDoctors` subcollection uses document existence to grant doctor access. This models collaborative access without relying on custom claims.

*QAPs (Rules are not Filters):*  The structure enables secure `list` operations by ensuring that rules can validate access without fetching additional documents. For example, listing health metrics under `/users/{userId}/health_metrics` only requires checking that the `request.auth.uid` matches the `userId` parameter in the path. Similarly, access to shared reports is controlled by existence within the `sharedWithDoctors` subcollection, ensuring that only authorized doctors can access them.
